SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Cases with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) have been anecdotally found to demonstrate relatively short axial lengths on ultrasound A-scans
This finding has not been rigorously documented
We therefore systematically investigated globe shape in these cases using computed tomography
METHODS: Computed tomographic 0.625-mm sections of 10 cases with IIH and 10 control subjects were reformatted on a workstation
Globe lengths and widths were measured from axial reformats
Globe lengths and heights were measured from oblique sagittal reformats
Two masked observers took all the measurements
RESULTS: The mean axial lengths of the globes of cases with IIH were significantly shorter than those of controls (t test for independent samples, P<0.001)
Both observers also found globe height to be significantly greater than globe length in oblique sagittal sections of cases with IIH compared with control subjects (Mann-Whitney U tests, P<0.01)
The difference between length and width in axial sections was not different between cases with IIH and control subjects

Using a critical cutoff of 0.6-mm difference between globe height and length in oblique sagittal sections returned a sensitivity of 0.75 and a specificity of 0.75 for IIH detection from both right and left eyes
CONCLUSIONS: There are significant differences in globe shape and axial length between cases with IIH and control subjects
The differences in globe shape manifest significantly only in oblique sagittal sections
This imaging sign could be a useful marker for subclinical IIH
